articles.headline: Moussaoui Now Ties Himself to 9/11 Plot
articles.snippet: Zacarias Moussaoui, who is facing the death penalty for the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, took the witness stand in his own defense Monday, only to bolster the government's case by unhesitatingly acknowledging the charges in the indictment ag...
articles.abstract: Zacarias Moussaoui, who is facing the death penalty for the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, took the witness stand in his own defense Monday, only to bolster the government's case by unhesitatingly acknowledging the charges in the indictment against him and adding a few new, self-incriminating statements.     Mr. Moussaoui said he knew in advance of Al Qaeda's plans to fly jetliners into the World Trade Center and asserted that his role on that day was to have been to fly another plane into the White House. He said he was to have been accompanied on the suicidal mission by Richard C. Reid, the so-called shoe bomber who was convicted in a separate failed effort to blow up a plane in flight.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 27 - Zacarias Moussaoui, who is facing the death penalty for the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, took the witness stand in his own defense Monday, only to bolster the government's case by unhesitatingly acknowledging the charges in the indictment against him and adding a few new, self-incriminating statements.

articles.headline: Bill to Broaden Immigration Law Gains in Senate
articles.snippet: With Republicans deeply divided, the Senate Judiciary Committee voted on Monday to legalize the nation's 11 million illegal immigrants and ultimately to grant them citizenship, provided that they hold jobs, pass criminal background checks, learn E...
articles.abstract: With Republicans deeply divided, the Senate Judiciary Committee voted on Monday to legalize the nation's 11 million illegal immigrants and ultimately to grant them citizenship, provided that they hold jobs, pass criminal background checks, learn English and pay fines and back taxes.     The panel also voted to create a vast temporary worker program that would allow roughly 400,000 foreigners to come to the United States to work each year and would put them on a path to citizenship as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 27 - With Republicans deeply divided, the Senate Judiciary Committee voted on Monday to legalize the nation's 11 million illegal immigrants and ultimately to grant them citizenship, provided that they hold jobs, pass criminal background checks, learn English and pay fines and back taxes.

articles.headline: Iraqi Documents Are Put on Web, and Search Is On
articles.snippet: American intelligence agencies and presidential commissions long ago concluded that Saddam Hussein had no unconventional weapons and no substantive ties to Al Qaeda before the 2003 invasion.     But now, an unusual experiment in public access is g...
articles.abstract: American intelligence agencies and presidential commissions long ago concluded that Saddam Hussein had no unconventional weapons and no substantive ties to Al Qaeda before the 2003 invasion.     But now, an unusual experiment in public access is giving anyone with a computer a chance to play intelligence analyst and second-guess the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 27 - American intelligence agencies and presidential commissions long ago concluded that Saddam Hussein had no unconventional weapons and no substantive ties to Al Qaeda before the 2003 invasion.

articles.headline: Riding High on a Tide of Oil
articles.snippet: Canada's wild west is going corporate.     In the last big energy boom in this province, during the 1970's, the card room at the Calgary Petroleum Club was so full of Texas oilmen that seats at the poker table were rarely freed up until well into ...
articles.abstract: Canada's wild west is going corporate.     In the last big energy boom in this province, during the 1970's, the card room at the Calgary Petroleum Club was so full of Texas oilmen that seats at the poker table were rarely freed up until well into the early morning hours.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT McMURRAY, Alberta - Canada's wild west is going corporate.

articles.headline: Lucent Talks Raise Issue of Security
articles.snippet: As merger talks between Lucent and Alcatel continue to advance, attention is turning to the role Lucent's fast-growing work for military and intelligence agencies may play in securing government approval for the trans-Atlantic deal.     With a lon...
articles.abstract: As merger talks between Lucent and Alcatel continue to advance, attention is turning to the role Lucent's fast-growing work for military and intelligence agencies may play in securing government approval for the trans-Atlantic deal.     With a long history of contributing to military efforts like ballistic missile technology and submarine sonar, the famed Bell Labs unit of Lucent is widely expected to become a focal point when the deal is presented to regulators in Washington for approval.
articles.lead_paragraph: As merger talks between Lucent and Alcatel continue to advance, attention is turning to the role Lucent's fast-growing work for military and intelligence agencies may play in securing government approval for the trans-Atlantic deal.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: In Russia, Ample Supply, Few Pipelines
articles.snippet: Once a tent camp for geologists, this Siberian settlement is here for only one reason: oil. A train to Moscow takes two days. Grocery stores sell reindeer meat. Summers run from the end of June to the beginning of August.      Despite its remote l...
articles.abstract: Once a tent camp for geologists, this Siberian settlement is here for only one reason: oil. A train to Moscow takes two days. Grocery stores sell reindeer meat. Summers run from the end of June to the beginning of August.      Despite its remote location in the far north, Usinsk has some inherent advantages. An export terminal a few hundred miles away on the Arctic Ocean could supply tankers able to reach the United States in nine days. Building a pipeline to Europe would feed the high-quality oil directly to another ravenous market.
articles.lead_paragraph: USINSK, Russia - Once a tent camp for geologists, this Siberian settlement is here for only one reason: oil. A train to Moscow takes two days. Grocery stores sell reindeer meat. Summers run from the end of June to the beginning of August.

articles.headline: G.M.'s Jobs Bank Looms as Major Obstacle on Road to Survival
articles.snippet: At the General Motors assembly plant on the barren outskirts of Oklahoma City there are 2,300 reminders of why the company needs to persuade tens of thousands of workers to take the buyouts it offered last week.      Each day, workers report for d...
articles.abstract: At the General Motors assembly plant on the barren outskirts of Oklahoma City there are 2,300 reminders of why the company needs to persuade tens of thousands of workers to take the buyouts it offered last week.      Each day, workers report for duty at the plant and pass their time reading, watching television, playing dominoes or chatting. Since G.M. shut down production there last month, these workers have entered the Jobs Bank, industry's best form of job insurance. It pays idled workers a full salary and benefits even when there is no work for them to do.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the General Motors assembly plant on the barren outskirts of Oklahoma City there are 2,300 reminders of why the company needs to persuade tens of thousands of workers to take the buyouts it offered last week.

articles.headline: A Surprise in Tax Case on KPMG
articles.snippet: The government's criminal case against 17 former KPMG employees over sales of questionable tax shelters took an unexpected turn yesterday when one of them, David Rivkin, pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy and tax evasion.     Mr. Rivkin, who ...
articles.abstract: The government's criminal case against 17 former KPMG employees over sales of questionable tax shelters took an unexpected turn yesterday when one of them, David Rivkin, pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy and tax evasion.     Mr. Rivkin, who was a KPMG partner in San Diego, agreed to cooperate with the government as part of his plea. His cooperation may help federal prosecutors in Manhattan build a case against the remaining defendants as well as help prosecutors in their widening inquiry into other accounting firms, banks, law firms and others that worked with KPMG to sell bogus tax shelters, lawyers not involved in the case said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government's criminal case against 17 former KPMG employees over sales of questionable tax shelters took an unexpected turn yesterday when one of them, David Rivkin, pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy and tax evasion.
articles.byline: By Lynnley Browning and Colin Moynihan

articles.headline: French Youth at the Barricades, But a Revolution? It Can Wait
articles.snippet: Adrien Reynaud is a revolutionary, but only part time.     A 20-year-old history major at the University of Avignon, in the south of France, he had been waging a round-the-clock protest against the new youth labor law, camping out with fellow prot...
articles.abstract: Adrien Reynaud is a revolutionary, but only part time.     A 20-year-old history major at the University of Avignon, in the south of France, he had been waging a round-the-clock protest against the new youth labor law, camping out with fellow protesters in two dozen tents pitched across the campus lawn.
articles.lead_paragraph: AVIGNON, France, March 25 - Adrien Reynaud is a revolutionary, but only part time.

articles.headline: Shiite Leaders Suspend Talks Over Government
articles.snippet: Frayed relations between Iraq's Shiite leadership and the American authorities came under increased strain on Monday as Shiite leaders angrily denounced a joint American-Iraqi raid on a Shiite compound and suspended negotiations over a new governm...
articles.abstract: Frayed relations between Iraq's Shiite leadership and the American authorities came under increased strain on Monday as Shiite leaders angrily denounced a joint American-Iraqi raid on a Shiite compound and suspended negotiations over a new government.      The raid on Sunday evening, which killed at least 16 people, also prompted the governor of Baghdad to announce a halt in cooperation with the American authorities, and Shiite militiamen to brandish their weapons in the streets of eastern Baghdad and declare their readiness to retaliate against American troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 27 - Frayed relations between Iraq's Shiite leadership and the American authorities came under increased strain on Monday as Shiite leaders angrily denounced a joint American-Iraqi raid on a Shiite compound and suspended negotiations over a new government.
